results.title: Why Haitians in Chile Keep Heading North to the U.S.
results.abstract: Many of the Haitian migrants who recently entered Texas had taken refuge for years in Chile. Some said they faced increasing joblessness, poverty and hostility there.

results.title: North Korea Launches Short-Range Missile as Country’s Envoy Speaks at U.N.

results.title: Wole Soyinka Is Not Going Anywhere
results.abstract: The Nobel laureate, whose new novel, “Chronicles From the Land of the Happiest People on Earth,” is his first in nearly 50 years, refuses to back down when he senses that his homeland’s freedom is under threat.
des_facet: Chronicles From the Land of the Happiest People on Earth (Book)

multimedia.caption: “Unfortunately, some of us are not very wise. We know what we ought to do, when we should retire, go and hide out somewhere, live a life of ease,” Wole Soyinka said. “But we don’t take our own advice, do we?”
multimedia.copyright: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times

results.title: ‘I Can’t Imagine a Good Future’: Young Iranians Increasingly Want Out
results.abstract: Divorce is up, fertility rates are down and many from Iran’s younger generation are postponing weddings and searching for ways to leave the country in the face of economic and political stagnation.

results.title: As Tunisia’s President Cements One-Man Rule, Opposition Grows
results.abstract: In his latest step to consolidate power, President Kais Saied set up a system under which he will essentially govern the country by decree, bypassing the Constitution.

multimedia.caption: President Kais Saied of Tunisia at the Carthage Palace, his official residence, in 2019. Mr. Saied froze Parliament, fired the prime minister and seized power on July 25.
multimedia.copyright: Khaled Nasraoui/picture alliance, via Getty Images)

results.title: Catalan Separatist Leaves Italy, Dodging Spain’s Latest Effort to Prosecute Him
results.abstract: After briefly holding Carles Puigdemont on a Spanish arrest warrant, Italian authorities released him, and he left the country on Monday.
results.byline: By Gaia Pianigiani and Emma Bubola

results.title: Sydney plans to start leaving its lockdown in October.
results.abstract: A phased reopening of Australia’s largest city is tied to reaching a series of milestones in vaccination rates.

results.title: Intimate Portraits of Mexico’s Third-Gender Muxes
results.abstract: On the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in southern Mexico, a community of the local Zapotec people has long accepted — and celebrated — gender nonconformity.

results.title: ‘Every Day Is Frightening’: Working for the Top U.S. Employer Amid Covid
results.abstract: As offices debate the merits and logistics of reopening, a parallel sphere of workers like Peter Naughton, a Walmart cashier, seem to inhabit another world. Often their jobs just got really hard.

multimedia.caption: Peter Naughton is a cashier and self-checkout host in Baton Rouge, La., at Walmart, the country’s largest private employer. He fears going to work — but also the idea of missing it.
multimedia.copyright: Emily Kask for The New York Times

results.title: N.Y.’s governor urges health care workers to ‘do the right thing’ and get shots.
results.abstract: “It’s not a role I relish,” Gov. Kathy C. Hochul said. “But I also realistically know that there are people who will not come back to their jobs.”
results.byline: By John Yoon, Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Joseph Goldstein

results.title: Vowing to modernize industry and ‘halt man-made climate change,’ Olaf Scholz claims a mandate.
results.abstract: The Social Democrats made significant gains on Sunday’s election but will need to find coalition partners to form a government.
